title: 113_s2620
content: The "Grid Reliability Act of 2014" may be cited as the Grid Reliability Act. It focuses on grid reliability. The Grid Reliability Act of 2014, also known as the Grid Reliability Act, amends Section 202(c) of the Federal Power Act to address temporary connection and exchange of facilities during emergencies. It includes provisions for administration of orders conflicting with environmental laws. The Grid Reliability Act of 2014 amends Section 202(c) of the Federal Power Act to allow temporary transmission of electric energy during emergencies, ensuring compliance with environmental laws and minimizing adverse impacts. Compliance with orders issued under this subsection may result in noncompliance with other laws. Orders issued under this subsection may conflict with other laws, but noncompliance with environmental laws will not result in liability or citizen suits. The Grid Reliability Act of 2014 amends Section 202(c) of the Federal Power Act to allow temporary transmission of electric energy during emergencies. The Commission can renew orders for up to 90 days, consulting with relevant federal agencies to minimize adverse environmental impacts. The Grid Reliability Act of 2014 allows temporary transmission of electric energy during emergencies. Conditions submitted by federal agencies must be made public. The Commission can exclude conditions if they hinder addressing the emergency and must provide an explanation. Orders can be stayed, modified, or set aside if necessary. The Grid Reliability Act of 2014 allows temporary transmission of electric energy during emergencies. Orders issued under this subsection can be stayed, modified, or set aside by a court. Section 202(d) of the Federal Power Act is amended to include municipalities.
